results.notes:
Cheilocystidia in mature specimens sparse, lageniform, or elongate-cylindrical with a rounded apex.

Pileipellis was a relatively simple cutis, with the upper layer of hyphae sparsely ornamented with small pegs and diverticulae: simple, unbranched, not conspicuous.

Hypoderm not “pseudoparenchymatous” with large open-structured cells, but rather of more densely packed hyphae.

Spores ~ 7 × 5 µm, pip-shaped, inamyloid.

Trama of cap not vinescent in Melzer’s.
results.location_name: Henry Cowell Redwoods State Park, Santa Cruz Co., California, USA

results.notes: Found scattered in the same living room sized spot with mostly Tan Oak, but also a redwood nearby where I have been finding this yellow variant for several years. Before the recent drought years, these yellows would be surrounded with acres of troops of normally dark pigmented Craterellus. Last couple years the yellows have reappeared, but the blacks have been very sparse.

results.notes:
On a decaying oak branch. Fruitbody massses up to 2 cm.

Larger spores 12-13 × 5-6. Hypobasidia ~15×13, epibasidia ~35×2.

Two common white jellies can be eliminated: Tremella encephala comes with two (not four) epibasidia, and Myxarium nucleatum has sausage-shaped spores.

results.notes:
On rotten wood of an oak log. The largest of the three mushrooms with cap 37 mm across, and stem 6 cm long.

Spores up to 7.5 microns long. Basidia ~33+4 x 9. Pleuro- and cheilocystidia similar, the size ranging from 44×14 to 108×35.

Everything seems to fit P. podospileus except for the absence of floccules on the stipe surface.

Specimens available and I can return to the site if anyone is interested in additional, more specific photos. Roo, I’d love to have your comments.

results.notes:
Habitat: oak woodland
Substrate: duff
Cap: 5.7 cm w; convex; context 9.5mm thick; context pure white did NOT discolor with handling or cutting; cuticle white w/reddish brown discoloration, concentrated heavier toward the center; medium size chunky white warts; appendiculate; odor very mild, indistinct, i.e. I can’t really smell anything
Gills: ivory white, adnexed
Stipe: 7.5 cm h; 2.5 cm thick right above the bulbous base tapering quickly to 1.27 cm at the top; base 5 cm h x ⅗ cm at it’s widest point near the top (of the base) tapering to a point, approximating the shape of a triangle; solid; remnants of an annulus could be seen with striations at the top of the stipe; odor indistinct; white with brownish red discorations on the exterior; it didn’t have a cup like volva, but there was an edge at the top of the base, but it was barely separated from it (see detail photo).
Spores: ? Waiting for spore prints
Notes: When I found this it had probably been handled or bumped into (by a human or animal); I found it with the cap next to the stipe. All parts discolored very little with handling; the mushroom was overall white with reddish brown discoloration on the cap and brownish red discoloration on the stipe, i.e. the stipe discolorations were more red toned, and the cap discolorations were more brown toned.

results.notes:
Habitat: oak woodland
Substrate: duff, near edge of road
Cap: 8 cm with x 5 cm high; context white, unchanging with cutting/handling; 12 mm at the disc gradually to thinning to the margin; hemispherical, slight flat top ; dry; brown scales; golden over creamy white; a couple small discolorations were reddish-orange; very slowly became more golden yellow with handling; appendiculate; slightly sweet, nutty odor; taste mild
Gills: ivory white; free
Stipe: 16 cm h x 3 cm thick, mostly appearing even with very gradual taper to 2 cm; outside coloring light golden over creamy white before what looks like very few remnants of an annulus, and ivory white above the remnants; appressed fibrillose, shaggier near the top of the stipe; cespitose growth in a cluster of 5 mushrooms, so slightly sinuous stipe and slightly bulbous where connected; not discoloring yellow like A. augustus (or what I thought were A. augustus) in the past; very slowly discoloring pale reddish brown only near the base, unchanging elsewhere; slightly sweet, nutty odor
Spores: ? (Waiting for spore print)

results.notes:
AN UPDATE ON THIS OBSERVATION IS POSTED AT http://mushroomobserver.org/231998

Resupinate polypore under bark and outer wood of White Oak (Quercus alba) log on ground. Log section was about 2 m long.
Fungus is mostly in a sealed space in woody layer several cm below bark and along the bottom of the entire length of the 2 m log. Pore surface purple-red (more so than in some of the photos) and soft to touch where no exposed. The outer wood layer detached readily; inner surface bright yellow. Yellow spores visible.
Two sets of photos from same log with dates showing:
1. February 16, 2016 – 6 photos
2. April 2, 2015 – 8 photos

results.notes:
Habitat: oak woodland
Substrate: duff
Cap: 5-11 cm; context of largest specimen 1 cm thick; context white with some red discolorations where worms had tunneled; convex to plane; one was ever so slightly upturned, and slightly depressed; glabrous; cuticle appeared translucent white with red blush marks; the red discoloration also was on some of the white warts; the warts were more concentrated toward the center and were more broken up and disintegrating toward the margin; margin non-striate; appendiculate; odor not distinctive
Gills: adnexed; white; some red discolorations
Stipe: 6-10 cm h x 2-3.5 cm w; white with some red discolorations where worms had tunneled; solid; slightly tapering to the apex; some indistinct bulbous, some with a non-abrupt rim; pointed at the base; skirt-like annulus with striations at the apex; pinkish brown fibrils below the annulus; odor not distinctive
Spores: ? (waiting for spore print)
Notes: The range in measurements are the smallest and largest specimens of a group of 4 mushrooms growing in a cluster (but not connected). There were red discolorations on all parts of the mushroom concentrated at the cap, the top of the bulbous base, and the bottom edge of the skirt-like annulus. When I cut and handled the mushroom there was no additional discoloration during the time of examination, but I’m going to say it must discolor with handling very slowly, because I could clearly see worm tunnels had caused red discoloration, and the worms were still there doing their business! These mushrooms were found in the same area (probably within 10’) of the mushroom I found on 2016-02-13, http://mushroomobserver.org/231274
results.location_name: Kingfisher Canyon, Avila Beach, San Luis Obispo Co., California, USA

results.notes:
Growing in small groups on rotten wood pieces and debris, in many places under a large fallen and decaying oak tree, its bark spread over a large area.

Basidia ~22×8. Spores 9.5-12 × 2.5-3.5. Cheilocystidia hard to extricate, mixed with basidia, sometimes in clumps. Basidia with visible sterigmata rare, except for the 1-spored kind, which I’m not sure are basidia at all; they might be cystidia, but mucronate cystidia are not mentioned for this species. Stipitipellis was not gelatinized (as descriptions say they should be). I struggled but couldn’t get a clear view/shot of the characteristic pseudoparenchymatous layer with the pileipellis on top. Surprising abundance and variety of diverticulate/branched hyphae in the pileipellis.

results.notes:
Growing on the ground near Live Oak.
Caps up to 6.8 cm across.
Prominent asymmetrical bulb at base of stem.
Spores ~ 7.0-9.0 X 5.3-7.0(8.0) microns, broadly ellipsoid to ellipsoid and moderately nodulose.
Cheilocystidia ~ 40-46 X 15-18 microns, utriform, some with apical encrustations.
Pleurocystidia ~ 50-75 X 14-17 microns, narrowly utriform, also with and without encrustations.
Odor not strong or distinctive.

results.notes:
1/2-2cm tall, brown, coral mushroom. Single stalk branches several times into flattened, fanning tips, fading from brown to whitish grey at tips. Highly gregarious under oak trees, emerging out of shallow oak leaf litter, attached to dirt, not litter layer. Spores highly lobed and irregular and approximately 7.5 um.
Sent to UCSC Fungal Herbarium for Accession.
results.location_name: San Joaquin River Gorge, Auberry, Fresno, California, USA
Berkeley Hills, Berkeley, Alameda Co., California, USA

results.notes:
Black fluted saddle fungus grown under oak tree canopy near stream, even emerging out of the stream water. 3-10 cm tall and 2-5 cm broad. black spore baring surface is convoluted, irregular or saddle like, grey on sterile underside. Stalk is highly folded, chambered and veined in a vertical orientation, often with holes in fold layers, equal to slightly tapered toward apex, white grey or black stem color.
Sent to UCSC Fungal Herbarium for Accession.
results.location_name: San Joaquin River Gorge, Auberry, Fresno, California, USA

results.notes:
11 cm tall club fungus growing out of oak leaf litter. Unbranched, tawny yellow-orange brown, tapering toward base, flattening slightly and wrinkling/folding towards apex.
Sent to UCSC Fungal Herbarium for Accession.

Spores are weakly amyloid
A few clamps on generative hyphae
Spores finely punctate but almost smooth

results.notes:
Growing by a trail, under oaks. Stalks (almost) entirely under ground surface.

Spores 17 × 11.5-12, perhaps immature (there were only a few free floating).

A week ago I found a bunch of Hellvela in the same place (2 m away) that were much smaller and darker and that I thought were H. leucomelaena; picture included. (I have that collection, but haven’t examined it.) Now I’m looking at the differences between H. leucomalaena and H. solitaria and it seems that the presence of absence of croziers (forked acus base) is a differentiator. And I think I’m seeing them now.

Mufindi, Mafinga, Iringa, Tanzania

results.notes:
One of a bunch of Cortinarii we collected this August. The forest was predominantly coniferous but otherwise a nightmare in terms of assigning mycorrhizal partnerships – a mixture of Picea obovata, Pinus sibirica (a five needle pine), Pinus sylvestris, Abies sibirica, Pinus sylvestris, and Betula pubescens, with an occasional Larix and Salix.
I tried keying it out in “Cortinarius in Sweden” keys but with little success. The spores are ellipsoid-amygdaloid, not very strongly verrucose, (7.9-) 8.0 – 10.2 (-10.3) x (5.1-) 5.2 – 6.0 (-6.7) µm, L =8.95, W = 5.58, Q = 1.6 (1.49 – 1.83) (n=36).
